channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Putin Says 16,000 New Recruits Have Deployed
item.description: The Kremlin has faced intensifying criticism from pro-war bloggers over the reported deaths of new recruits fighting in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: A destroyed Russian military vehicle near Mykolaivka in the Kherson region on Sunday.

item.title: Live Updates: U.K. Government Reverses Course on Fiscal Plan That Rattled Markets
item.description: Prime Minister Liz Truss vowed to raise the country’s corporate tax rate, reversing a plan that had been outlined in a set of measures that her government proposed last month. She also fired Kwasi Kwarteng, her finance minister.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Tolga Akmen/EPA, via Shutterstock

item.title: French Refineries Strike May Presage a Winter of Discontent for Europe
item.description: Bitten by inflation, workers are demanding a greater share of the surging profits of energy giants. It’s the kind of unrest leaders fear as they struggle to keep a united front against Russia.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Porter and Constant Méheut
item.media:credit: Andrea Mantovani for The New York Times
item.media:description: Outside the Total refinery in Gonfreville-l’Orcher, just outside of Le Havre, France, on Thursday, union members burned wood palettes, hoisted flags and voted to continue a strike.

item.title: Xi Jinping, China’s Leader, Embodies His Authoritarian Era
item.description: Xi Jinping was first cast as a firm but genial leader with a common touch. Approaching a second decade in power, he looms over China like a stern Communist monarch.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley
item.media:credit: Thomas Peter/Reuters
item.media:description: Xi Jinping on a giant screen at an event last year in Beijing’s National Stadium to commemorate the 100th anniversary of the founding of the Communist Party of China.

item.title: How Two Teenagers Became the New Faces of Iran’s Protests
item.description: The 16-year-old girls were killed by the Iranian security services in a crackdown on the protests that have rocked the country for the past month.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Can Russia Keep Firing Missiles at Ukrainian Cities?
item.description: Efforts to help Ukraine shield its cities may depend on the scarcity of both Russian missiles and Western air defense systems.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: Smoke rising over Kyiv, the Ukrainian capital, on Monday after Russian missile strikes.

item.title: Turkey Allows Jail Terms for What It Deems ‘Fake News’
item.description: Rights advocates fear the government could use newly passed legislation to restrict speech and target critics in the run-up to crucial elections in June.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard and Safak Timur
item.media:credit: Petr David Josek/Associated Press
item.media:description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey last week in Prague. Mr. Erdogan had argued that the newly passed legislation was necessary to fight disinformation.

item.title: With Leaps and Bounds, Parkour Athletes Turn Off the Lights in Paris
item.description: As an energy crisis looms, nimble young activists are using superhero-like moves to switch off wasteful lights that stores leave on all night.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Kevin Ha, 30, left, leader of the On The Spot Parkour collective in Paris, climbs a wall to turn off a shop’s exterior lights on the Avenue des Champs-Élysées, in September.

item.title: North Korea Tests a Missile and Flies Warplanes Near Border With South
item.description: South Korea dispatched its own warplanes in a show of force as the North appeared intent on keeping tensions high on the Korean Peninsula.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:credit: Ahn Young-Joon/Associated Press
item.media:description: A news program showing a North Korean missile launch, on a screen at the Seoul Railway Station on Thursday.

item.title: Amid Turmoil, Can Liz Truss Afford to Hold on to Tax-Cutting Plan?
item.description: Prime Minister Liz Truss and her chancellor of the Exchequer, Kwasi Kwarteng, say they are holding steady on their plans, but experts believe concessions are inevitable.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:credit: Oli Scarff/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Prime Minister Liz Truss speaking at the Conservative Party conference this month in Birmingham.

item.title: Iraqi Parliament Elects Abdul Latif Rashid as New President
item.description: The vote is the first step to forming a new government after a year of political deadlock and heightened instability.
item.dc:creator: Jane Arraf
item.media:credit: Iraqi Parliament, via Reuters
item.media:description: Iraqi lawmakers attended a parliamentary session on Thursday to vote for a new president in Baghdad.

item.title: Death Toll Rises as Russia Bombards Ukraine’s Cities for a Fourth Day
item.description: Prompted by the expanded strikes, European countries made plans to develop joint air defenses and to train Ukrainian soldiers on European Union soil.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff and Eric Nagourney
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers with a destroyed Russian tank near the village of Pisky-Radkivski in the Donetsk region on Thursday.

item.title: No New Trial in Murder Mystery That Gripped France, Court Rules
item.description: Omar Raddad was convicted in the 1991 killing of a wealthy widow, but scant evidence and a grammatical error sowed doubts about his guilt. He sought a retrial based on new DNA evidence.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.media:credit: Alain Jocard/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Omar Raddad, center, a Moroccan-born gardener convicted of killing his employer in 1991, at a hearing on his request for a new trial, in Paris last year.

item.title: Inquiry on Trudeau Using Emergency Powers on Trucker Protests Begins
item.description: Lawyers for the Canadian government and opponents clashed on whether the government had been justified in using the powers during protests that paralyzed Ottawa last February.
item.dc:creator: Norimitsu Onishi
item.media:credit: Sean Kilpatrick/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau of Canada this month at the House of Commons on Parliament Hill in Ottawa.

item.title: Elon Musk Says SpaceX Can’t Fund Internet Service in Ukraine ‘Indefinitely’
item.description: Starlink terminals have been critical in allowing the Ukrainian military to coordinate on the battlefield, including in recent offensives.
item.dc:creator: Cassandra Vinograd
item.media:credit: Taras Podolian/ Global Images Ukraine, via Getty Images
item.media:description: A SpaceX Starlink internet terminal in Vorzel, Ukraine.

item.title: China’s Internet Censors Race to Quell Beijing Protest Chatter
item.description: Some search terms were banned, WeChat accounts suspended and songs removed to stop discussion of a rare public protest denouncing Xi Jinping.
item.dc:creator: Daisuke Wakabayashi and Claire Fu
item.media:credit: Dake Kang/Associated Press
item.media:description: An intersection near a Beijing bridge, where social media videos appeared to show smoke and protest banners on Thursday. Covid-19 policies were among the criticisms raised.

item.title: Herschel Walker’s Polling Dip
item.description: How the Senate race in Georgia is shaking out.
item.dc:creator: Nate Cohn
item.media:credit: Nicole Craine for The New York Times
item.media:description: Herschel Walker.

item.title: Father Joe, Bangkok’s Priest to the Poor, Thrives Among Fellow Outcasts
item.description: For 50 years, the Rev. Joseph Maier has lived in one of the poorest parts of the Thai capital, ministering to Catholics, Buddhists and Muslims alike, and never finding favor with the church hierarchy.
item.dc:creator: Seth Mydans
item.media:credit: Lauren DeCicca for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Rev. Joseph H. Maier visiting a kindergarten class last month at the community center he founded in one of the poorest areas of Bangkok.

item.title: Beyond Borders: A Deep Dive Into the Nomadic Way of Life
item.description: Anthony Sattin, the author of a new book on nomadic groups, discusses how contemporary travelers and digital nomads can learn a few things from traditional cultures.
item.dc:creator: David Farley
item.media:credit: Sylvie Franquet
item.media:description: Anthony Sattin’s research for his new book, “Nomads: The Wanderers Who Shaped Our World,” included years of travels with modern-day nomadic peoples in the Middle East, Africa and beyond. Above, the author, in northern Iran.

item.title: The Future of Australian Children’s TV
item.description: It might make more economic sense for all English-language programming to be made in Los Angeles, but that would come at a different cost.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Ludo Studio/Disney Channel, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A scene from the animated series “Bluey”.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing
item.description: A fourth day of Russian bombardment.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Emergency services workers removed rubble on Wednesday from the site of a missile strike in Zaporizhzhia that killed eight people on Monday.

item.title: As Immigration Issue Looms, Biden Officials Turn Eye to Latin America
item.description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken, just back from South America, met again with his Mexican counterpart.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.category: United States Agency for International Development
item.media:credit: Alex Brandon/Associated Press
item.media:description: Marcelo Ebrard, Mexico’s foreign minister, met with U.S. Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken for the second time in just over a month.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing: U.S. Inflation Keeps Soaring
item.description: Plus Europe’s search for energy and U.S. attempts to hinder China’s technological development.
item.dc:creator: Daniel E. Slotnik

item.title: Hurricane Ian’s Financial Toll Threatens Florida’s Real Estate Market
item.description: The hurricane’s record-breaking cost will make it even harder for many to get insurance, experts say — threatening home sales, mortgages and construction.
item.dc:creator: Christopher Flavelle
item.media:credit: Callaghan O'Hare for The New York Times
item.media:description: Cleanup in the aftermath of Hurricane Ian in Fort Myers Beach, Fla., on Oct. 5.

item.title: Putin Offers to Make Turkey a Gas Hub to Preserve EU Energy Hold
item.description: Energy experts have questioned the viability of the Russian president’s proposal, saying it seemed unlikely that the bloc would approve new pipelines for Russian gas to Europe.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins, Safak Timur and Stanley Reed
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Vyacheslav Prokofyev
item.media:description: Russian President Vladimir V. Putin, right, meeting with Turkey’s president, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, in Astana, Kazakhstan, on Thursday.

item.title: With New Crackdown, Biden Wages Global Campaign on Chinese Technology
item.description: U.S. officials pushed to choke off China’s access to critical semiconductor technology after internal debates and tough negotiations with allies.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson and Edward Wong
item.media:credit: How Hwee Young/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: An effort by the Biden administration would try to use U.S. influence over global technology and supply chains to choke off China’s access to advanced chips and chip production tools needed to power those abilities.

item.title: Saudi Arabia and U.S. Trade Accusations Over Oil Cuts
item.description: The kingdom said it had rejected the Biden administration’s urging for a one-month delay to the reduction in output. That could have prevented a price spike before the American midterm elections.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard
item.category: Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries
item.media:credit: Ahmed Jadallah/Reuters
item.media:description: A Saudi oil refinery in 2018. The Saudi Foreign Ministry expressed in a statement on Thursday the kingdom’s “total rejection” of the idea that it was playing politics with its oil.

item.title: What Happened to Monkeypox?
item.description: Why cases suddenly began to decline.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez
item.media:credit: Mike Kai Chen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Positive monkeypox samples at the Renegade Bio processing lab from August.

item.title: Kyiv Region of Ukraine Hit by Suspected ‘Kamikaze’ Drones
item.description: The weapons are causing havoc in a region that had been largely spared since the early months of the war.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia and Victoria Kim
item.media:credit: Gleb Garanich/Reuters
item.media:description: Outside a building destroyed in a Russian attack using an Iranian-made drone in Bila Tserkva, southwest of Kyiv, last week.

item.title: Inside the Global Effort to Keep Perfectly Good Food Out of the Dump
item.description: Around the world, lawmakers and entrepreneurs are taking steps to tackle two of humanity’s most pressing problems: hunger and climate change.
item.dc:creator: Somini Sengupta
item.media:credit: Andri Tambunan for The New York Times
item.media:description: Vue Vang collected donated food from a Trader Joe’s in Fresno, Calif., where, under a new law, grocery stores are required to donate “the maximum amount of edible food that would otherwise be disposed.”

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: Western support for Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: A recently dug grave prepared for a military funeral at a cemetery in Bucha, Ukraine, on Wednesday.

item.title: Germany Needs Coal to Replace Gas, So a Village Has to Go
item.description: The cutting of Russian gas supplies to Europe has led Germany to step up coal use, despite its goal to phase it out by 2030.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze and Erika Solomon
item.media:credit: Ingmar Nolting for The New York Times
item.media:description: An excavator working at the Garzweiler open-pit coal mine in Germany in August. The prospect of a winter without cheap Russian gas has dampened interest in greener policies.

item.title: Ukraine Offensive Will Push Through Winter, US Defense Chief Says
item.description: The “deliberate cruelty” of Russia’s latest bombardment has made the West more determined to help Ukraine, Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III said.
item.dc:creator: John Ismay
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: A worker in Zaporizhzhia, Ukraine, on Wednesday salvaged tools from what was left of an auto-body shop, which was destroyed by a missile strike on Wednesday that killed one person.

item.title: The 2022 Living Planet Index Is Out. Here’s How to Understand It.
item.description: The latest update to an important assessment found that populations had declined by an average of 69 percent since 1970. But that might not mean what you think.
item.dc:creator: Catrin Einhorn
item.media:credit: Miguel Zambrano/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A conservation biologist in Mérida State, Venezuela, in April. Wednesday’s report looks at how specific populations are changing over time, not overall losses.

item.title: Western Nations Rush Defensive Systems to Ukraine to Counter Russian Missiles
item.description: Even with Soviet-era defensive weapons, the Ukrainians have been more than holding their own, but this week’s barrage prompted calls to better equip them.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz, Lara Jakes and Eric Schmitt
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: Damage from the Russian bombing in Ukraine’s capital, Kyiv.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing: China’s Covid Testing Problems
item.description: Plus President Biden’s security strategy and Myanmar cracks down on journalists.
item.dc:creator: Daniel E. Slotnik
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrié for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Covid testing booth in Beijing.

item.title: Liz Truss Stirs Uncertainty Over the U.K.’s Economic Plans
item.description: Prime Minister Liz Truss appeared to rule out cuts in public spending, as doubts about the fiscal soundness of the government’s program continued to roil the markets.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
item.media:credit: Tolga Akmen/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Prime Minister Liz Truss leaving to address Parliament on Wednesday.

item.title: Britain’s ‘Brexit Festival’ Is Under Investigation
item.description: The festival, a series of exhibitions officially called “Unboxed: Creativity in the U.K.,” came to be known as the “Festival of Brexit.” It cost 120 million pounds.
item.dc:creator: Saskia Solomon
item.media:credit: Emily Macinnes for The New York Times
item.media:description: Spectators watched as Paisley Abbey was illuminated for an art installation during an “Unboxed: Creativity in the U.K.” event, in Paisley, Scotland, earlier this year.

item.title: In Long-Contested Move, Paris Makes Sacré-Coeur a Historical Monument
item.description: The basilica, which sits atop the hill of Montmartre, is the second most visited site in the capital, after Notre-Dame.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:credit: Andrea Mantovani for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Sacré-Coeur Basilica in Paris. Paris’s City Council voted Tuesday to classify the Sacré-Coeur as a “historical monument.”

item.title: US Considers Easing Sanctions on Venezuela as Migration Surges
item.description: The Biden administration may allow the last American company producing oil in Venezuela to resume exports if the Maduro government takes steps to restore democracy.
item.dc:creator: Natalie Kitroeff and Anatoly Kurmanaev
item.media:credit: Federico Rios for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Venezuelan family crossing the Darién Gap between Colombia and Panama last month.

item.title: Biden’s National Security Strategy Focuses on China, Russia and Democracy at Home
item.description: The document, which every new administration is required to issue, was delayed last winter as it became clear that Russia’s invasion of Ukraine was imminent.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Erin Schaff/The New York Times
item.media:description: In his strategy document, President Biden returned to a theme he has established since his second month in office, describing a coming struggle as one of autocracies versus democracies.

item.title: Brittney Griner Is Struggling in Russian Prison, Her Lawyer Says
item.description: Facing nine years in prison in Russia, the U.S. basketball star is struggling emotionally and worried that a swap deal to release her may not materialize, according to one of her attorneys.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins and Michael Crowley
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Kirill Kudryavtsev
item.media:description: Brittney Griner at a court outside Moscow in August. The United States has said that her detention and trial were politically motivated.

item.title: Poland Says Druzhba Pipeline Leak Was Probably an Accident
item.description: News of the episode raised energy security concerns, but a Polish energy official said there was no reason to suspect sabotage.
item.dc:creator: Stanley Reed
item.media:credit: Kacper Pempel/Reuters
item.media:description: Firefighters near the Druzhba pipeline in Poland where an oil leak was detected on Wednesday.

item.title: Abortion Bans Weigh on Republicans
item.description: Banning abortion is weighing on the party.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Lerer
item.media:credit: Shuran Huang for The New York Times

item.title: China’s Covid-Testing Strategy Comes Under Strain
item.description: Bills are piling up and infections are spreading, yet there are no signs that Beijing plans to rethink a cornerstone of its pandemic policy.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson and Zixu Wang
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrié for The New York Times

item.title: When a Country’s Cuisine Becomes a Cultural Export
item.description: South Korea has sought to protect and enshrine its national dishes — while also sharing its wonders with the world.
item.dc:creator: Ligaya Mishan and David Chow
item.category: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization

item.title: The E-Bike: The New Car Alternative
item.description: VanMoof, the Dutch e-bike company taking inspiration from Apple and Tesla, is one of the world’s hottest brands in a bike market remade by the pandemic. Will it help reshape urban transportation?
item.dc:creator: Adam Satariano
item.media:credit: Matt Williams

item.title: Books About London That Take You Through the City
item.description: Bernardine Evaristo, whose “Girl, Woman, Other” won the Booker Prize, invites readers into London, a city whose rich literary landscape is “for everyone, not just the privileged few.”
item.dc:creator: Bernardine Evaristo
item.category: The Five: The Untold Lives of the Women Killed by Jack the Ripper (Book)
item.media:credit: Raphaelle Macaron

item.title: Russia Arrests 8 People Over the Crimea Bridge Attack
item.description: Five are citizens of Russia, according to Russia’s domestic intelligence agency, the F.S.B., and the others are Ukrainian and Armenian.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz and John Ismay
item.media:credit: Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Smoke billowing from a fire on the Kerch Strait Bridge linking Crimea to Russia on Saturday.

item.title: Protests in Iran Spread, Including to Oil Sector, Despite Violent Crackdown
item.description: Human rights groups say at least 185 people have been killed and thousands injured or arrested, but demonstrations that began after the death of Mahsa Amini have continued nearly a month.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi and Jane Arraf
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Tehran, the capital, on Sunday.

item.title: Young Journalists Fight to Keep Free Press Alive in Myanmar
item.description: The Southeast Asian nation has seen a relentless crackdown on free expression, with a small literary magazine emerging as one of the few remaining independent media outlets.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:credit: The New York Times
item.media:description: Myanmar is now one of the world’s most dangerous places for journalists after the army seized power in a coup last year.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.description: Calls for more weapons for Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: A wave of attacks by Russia in Ukraine’s capital, Kyiv, left a large crater in a playground.

item.title: Some Ukrainians Brace for Possibility of Russian Nuclear Strike
item.description: Fears of more severe retaliation grew after the attack on Russia’s sole bridge to Crimea. But U.S. officials have said they think the chances of Moscow’s using nuclear weapons are low.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: Running from the scene of a Russian bombing in Kyiv, Ukraine, on Monday. Moscow responded to the assault on the Kerch Strait Bridge with a series of missile attacks across Ukraine.

item.title: Pressure Grows for West to Give Ukraine Air-Defense Systems
item.description: After Russia bombarded civilian targets, G7 leaders pledged “undeterred and steadfast” financial and military support for Kyiv.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger, Eric Schmitt, Michael Schwirtz and Eric Nagourney
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: A wave of attacks by Russia in Ukraine’s capital, Kyiv, left a large crater in a playground.

item.title: Biden: Putin ‘Totally Miscalculated’ on Reaction to Ukraine Invasion
item.description: In an interview with CNN, Mr. Biden said he had “no intention” of talking to the Russian leader at a meeting next month, but would consider discussions about freeing Brittney Griner.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear
item.media:credit: Cheriss May for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden at the White House on Tuesday.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing: Ukraine Seeks an ‘Air Shield’
item.description: Plus Xi Jinping’s push for an indivisible Chinese identity and a warning for the global economy.
item.dc:creator: Daniel E. Slotnik
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: A resident stood on her balcony opposite a heavily damaged building, struck by a Russian missile a day earlier in Dnipro, Ukraine, on Tuesday.
